Dear Mr. Williams:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
01/16/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MSA
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except
for the following:
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two out of eight applicable foster care case records reviewed contained one late
updated service plan each by two and 15 days.
Repeat Citation from 02/06/2018 Interim Inspection Report
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the service
plan must address the living arrangement for the child or
children, visitation/parenting time with the youth’s biological
children or a clear explanation why this is not possible or
appropriate.
Two out three independent living records reviewed contained late updated service
plans by one and 15 days.
Repeat Citation from 02/06/2018 Interim Inspection Report
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
4

One out of three independent living records reviewed did not contain an initial or
quarterly independent living contracts.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.18 Page Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness (Commitment
23 54).
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative
foster parents within 180 days of the date of placement.
The agency has 25 relatives in the process of licensing that extend beyond 180
days. Patterns of lateness include receiving referrals after months of placement,
relative follow through, housing issues, criminal history, permanency plan changes,
request for variances, pending waivers and denials.
Repeat Citation from the 02/06/2018 Interim Inspection report
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS
MiSACWIS
(Commitment DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
22). welfare information system which will be the primary tracking
system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
One FTM was present in the hard file though not uploaded into MiSACWIS.
One unannounced visit documented on a progress note form was not identified as
an unannounced home visit in MiSACWIS.
Repeat Citation from the 02/06/2018 Interim Inspection Report

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Supervisory Approval – USP
FOM 722-09
Page 27
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
Six out of eight applicable foster care case records reviewed contained late
supervisor signatures on treatment plans. Five signatures were late between one
and three days, whereas three were late between 15 and 33 days.
Repeat Citation from 02/06/2018 Interim Inspection Report
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Parents and Youth
FOM 722-08C over 14-Years Old
Page 2
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and
service agreement, the parent is given a copy for review. Foster
care workers need to ensure the parent understands all areas
within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or
refuses to sign the PATP, foster care workers must identify, and
document additional action needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the PATP. As the goals are achieved, modified or
expanded, the updated PATP will reflect this process. Parents
and youths age 14 and older must participate in the
development of each updated treatment plan, allowing for
opportunity to evaluate their progress towards completing goals.
Two out three independent living records reviewed were deficient youth signatures
on one treatment plan each.
DHHS Policy - Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction
FOM 722-06I -
Page 11-12
Siblings not placed together shall have at least one visit per
month unless the visit may be harmful to one or more of the
6

siblings, the sibling is placed out-of-state, the distance between
the sibling's placements is more than 50 miles and one child is
placed with a relative, or one of the siblings is above the age of
16 and refuses such visits (The above visit exceptions must be
recorded in MiSACWIS). The plan for sibling visits and all
reasonable efforts to assure that visits take place must be
documented within the sibling visitation section of the case
service plan.
One out of eight applicable foster care records reviewed did not document monthly
sibling visits as occurring for two report periods.
DHHS Policy Unannounced Home Visit – Caseworker Contact with
FOM 722-6H – Caregivers
Page 7
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in
the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If there are two
caregivers, such as a primary and secondary caregiver, the
caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the
secondary caregiver in the home at least once each quarter.
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the home
every quarter. The unannounced visit must be documented in
MiSACWIS.
One out of eight foster care records reviewed were deficient unannounced visits for
two report periods.
Repeat Citation from the 02/06/2018 Interim Inspection Report
DHHS Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Communication Documentation Requirements
Issuance 17-099
All treatment plans with a report date of August 1, 2017, or later
must have signatures from all appropriate case members within
30 days of the report date.
Two out of eight foster care records reviewed contained birth or foster parent
signatures on treatment plans beyond 30 days of the report date.
Two out three independent living records reviewed contained youth signatures on
treatment plans beyond 30 days of the report date.
7

Page 9-10
Was a DHHS-643, [Permanency Goal Review] completed
annually from the point that the goal was changed to PPFWR &
APPLA?
Two out of three applicable independent living records reviewed did not contain an
annual permanency goal review from the point the youth was changed to APPLA.
Repeat Citation from the 02/06/2018 Interim Inspection Report
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
DHHS Policy Health Documentation.
FOM 801 Pages
2-25 All health requirements are to be documented and maintained
as follows:
•Age-specific Well Child Exam form.
An independent living youth’s case was transferred to the agency in 10/18.
MiSACWIS indicates a Care Connect physical examination occurring on 07/09/2018
though the Age-specific Well Child Exam form was not uploaded by the previous
agency. It is recommended that the agency review youth records for Age-specific
Well Child Exam forms in MiSACWIS and request them when Care Connect notes
them as being completed, but not uploaded.
R 400.12422 Foster care record.
(2) An agency shall protect each record against destruction and
damage and shall store and maintain each child’s record in a
manner to assure confidentiality and to prevent unauthorized
access.
An independent living youth’s 30-day assessment was uploaded into another youth’s
case record in MiSACWIS. It is noted that the youths first and last name initials are
the same.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
8

DHHS Policy - Referral to Adoption.
ADM 210 - Page
5 Within three working days of the assignment of the adoption
caseworker, the adoption worker must notify the caregivers with
whom the child is placed that the child’s permanency plan is
adoption. The caregiver’s interest in adoption must be
documented. Relatives who previously expressed interest in
placement must be contacted. The foster parent and relatives
must be given a DHHS-4809 to document their interest.
The agency utilizes a database form to capture the timeframes of this policy
requirement. The form does not capture the intent to adopt signature or progress
note indicating when the case manager discussed the matter with the foster parent.
It is recommended that the database form capture such information and the means
of such information being captured, i.e.: intent to adopt form or progress note.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the 02/06/2018 interim inspection
report. The corrective actions plan successfully addressed the following as no
repeat citations are noted: personnel references, reevaluation compliance
documentation, foster parent information, timely ISP, timely 30-day transfer
summaries, IL location at termination, medical passports, sibling visits, FTM’s, and
submitting permanency packets. Repeat citations include: late foster care and IL
USP’s, documentation uploaded into MISACWIS, relative licensure within 180 days,
supervisor approvals within 14-days, unannounced visits, and annual APPLA
permanency goal reviews.
The agency also submitted a corrective action plan for SIR#2018C0219022
regarding the reporting of foster home noncompliance for investigation by a case
manager. This CAP appears to have been effective as no repeat citations are
noted.
Safety and Concern Alert #1:
Urgent: It appears the furnace in the home is not working. During the visit
the home was cold. The children were wearing their coats.
9

Resolution: The agency conducted a home visit on 01/11/2019.
The temperature was noted at 77 degrees and the furnace
operable. The relative reports the furnace being turned off during
the day to reduce heating costs. The analyst visited the home at
4:30PM, which was the same time the relative returned home and
reason for the home being cold on 01/10/2019. Another home visit
was conducted on 01/15/2019 in which the temperature in the
home was registered at 77 degrees. Picture submitted.
Critical: The backdoor is blocked with items which does not allow access to
the door.
Resolution: The agency conducted a home visit on 01/15/2019.
The backdoor area was observed to be free of items. Picture
submitted.
Critical: The kitchen door is not attached to the hinges
Resolution: The agency conducted a home visit on 01/15/2019 and
noted the pocket door in the kitchen had been removed. Picture
provided.
Critical: There was some form of backup in the basement.
Resolution: The agency conducted a home visit on 01/15/2019 and
observed no dried paper on the floor in the basement. It is reported
that the previous tenants of the home experienced a backup with
the drain and did not clean the floor of the debris which dried and
hardened. Picture provided.
Concern: There is concern relative being required to repay the agency
$8,842.08. The foster parent/relative only has a limited source of
income.
Resolution: Relative received both Social Security benefits and
foster care payments for the four relatives placed in her home, thus
creating an $8,842.08 overpayment in foster care payments. The
agency worked with relative to ensure that the SSI benefits were
discontinued and restarted the foster care payments. Relative
signed a repayment plan with the agency and agreed to the
withholding of $250 per pay period from her foster parent check. In
an effort to defray the $250 taken out of relatives check the agency
arranged the following for relative during the holiday season: $100
Kroger gift card for Thanksgiving dinner, providing winter coats for
all the children, assigning relative to a corporate donor who
purchased toys, clothing, shoes, household items and a $500
Meijer gift card. The four relative placements were each given
10

$150 Meijer gift cards during “Shop with a Detroit Lion” event.
Relative also received a couch, twin bed, and several dressers
ordered and paid for by an agency board member.
Safety and Concern Alert #2:
Urgent: The foster parents are waiting for reimbursement in the amount of
$583.54. This reimbursement was for their last placement’s senior
activities. According to the foster parent the assigned foster care
worker instructed the foster parents to pay for the items and they
would be reimbursed. It has been more than 5 months with no
follow up. Attached is the price list for what was spent.
Resolution: The foster parents submitted receipts to the agency
for expenses paid for graduation/senior class activities for youth in
06/2018. The agency submitted the receipts to DHHS, via
MiSACWIS, to access Youth in Transition (YIT) funding on
06/12/2018. The request remains as “pending approval” by DHHS
in MiSACWIS as of 01/17/2019.
Safety and Concern Alert #3:
No safety or concerns noted.
Safety and Concern Alert #4:
Urgent: There were beeping smoke detectors in the home.
Resolution: Foster parent was contacted on 12/12/2018 to discuss
the beeping smoke detectors. The agency conducted a home visit
on 12/12/2018 and it was noted that the batteries had been
replaced and are no longer beeping.
Safety and Concern Alert #5:
No safety or concerns noted.
Safety and Concern Alert #6:
Urgent: Relative. The foster parent does not have a medical passport for
the child placed in the home.
11

Resolution: The child was placed with relative prior to the agency
accepting case responsibility on 11/13/2018. The service plan
period for the child ended on 01/01/2019. The relative signed the
medical passport for the report period on 01/19/2019 and after the
analyst visit.
Safety and Concern Alert #7:
Concern: Relative. No available crib in a home licensed to accept infants,
however no infants are currently in the home.
Resolution: On 01/17/2019 the agency contacted the foster parent
to ask about her crib. The foster parent indicates the previous child
who was discharged from the home on 02/04/2018 had been biting
the side of the crib. Foster parent consequently threw out the crib.
The agency offered relative assistance in the purchase of another
crib, which the foster parent declined and asked to voluntarily close
her license effective 01/17/2019.
Concern: The agency does not provide all known information regarding the
child when requesting placement.
Resolution: The foster parent signed the Case Management
Replacement/Service plan confirming that all known case
information was shared with her when foster child was placed in her
home on 08/29/2018.
Safety and Concern Alert #8:
No safety or concerns noted.
Safety and Concern Alert #9:
Concern: One of the bedrooms could not be viewed. There was a padlock on
the door, the unlicensed relative did not have the key. This room
will be used for the foster child according to the relative.
Resolution: The agency conducted a home visit on 01/17/2019 and
reviewed with the unlicensed relative that bedroom doors cannot
have locks on the outside of the door. Youth and relative reported
placing a lock on the bedroom when not at home as a result of birth
mother breaking into the relative home and stealing youth’s
12

belongings on two occasions. The agency has purchased a
lockable storage bench for the youth to place her valuables.
Safety and Concern Alert #10:
Urgent: The home does not have a carbon monoxide detector
Resolution: The agency purchased a carbon monoxide detector
and installed it at the unlicensed relative home on 12/19/2018.
Concern: Youth over the age of 14 indicates not being involved in the
development of the case service plan or goals, signing the semi-
annual transitional meeting, not working on independent living
skills, or is aware of MYOI services.
Resolution: Youth participated in and signed the last treatment
plan dated 09/30/2018, which addresses independent living skills
and notes youth not wanting to participate in MYOI services though
offered. Semi-annual transition plans were signed by the youth on
08/10/2017 and 01/17/2019.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
